article.headline: An estimated 9 million low-income Americans are eligible for stimulus checks but havenât gotten them yet
article.body: Some 9 million Americans may still be waiting on their stimulus checks. MARKETWATCH PHOTO ILLUSTRATION/ISTOCKPHOTO An estimated 9 million Americans who make less than $12,000 a year may be eligible for pandemic relief checks but havenât received them yet, and the clock is ticking if they want to get the money this year. They have until Oct. 15 to claim the payment by registering with the Internal Revenue Service. If they fail to meet the deadline, theyâll have to wait until 2021 to get the payment, according to the IRS.But these low-income Americans may want to think twice before registering to get the money, experts told MarketWatch. If they use the IRS portal to claim their stimulus payment now, they could be delayed in receiving an important federal benefit: the Earned Income Tax Credit. The IRS is mailing letters to the 9 million individuals starting on Sept. 24 outlining details about eligibility and information on how to claim their stimulus checks. âIf you were not required to file a 2019 federal income tax return, the best and fastest way to claim your Economic Impact Payment is to visit IRS.gov/eip by October 15,â the letter states. After Oct. 15, the only way to receive an unclaimed stimulus check is âto file a federal income tax return,â the letter states.Â Most Americans who got stimulus checks received the money either through a direct deposit into their bank accounts, or with a paper check in the mail. The IRS used address and bank account information it had on file from peopleâs tax returns. But Americans who earn under $12,200 a year arenât required to file federal income tax returns, according to the IRS. Thatâs made it more difficult for the IRS, the agency responsible for distributing stimulus checks, to get stimulus checks to these individuals. “ Unlike the majority of Americans who received their stimulus checks automatically, the estimated 9 million Americans who have yet to receive their stimulus checks are mostly earning under $12,000 a year and typically donât file federal income tax returns. ” âPeople who normally donât file a tax return shouldnât wait to see if they receive one of these letters,â IRS Commissioner Chuck Rettig said in a statement on Sept. 8. âThey can review the guidelines and register now if theyâre eligible.â But thereâs a significant catch: The letter the IRS will be sending out âfails to provide other options to taxpayers such as a mail-in form as an alternative to using the online portal,â said Nancy Rossner, a senior staff attorney at the Community Tax Law Project. Thatâs important because âusing the portal essentially acts like filing an electronic return, and so it prevents that taxpayer from actually being able to file electronically for 2019 if they have first used the portal.â “ âTaxpayers who use the portal to claim their stimulus checks will need to file a paper return to claim the EITC which may take several weeks if not months to process as the IRS is still trying to catch up on its backlog of mail.â ” â Nancy Rossner, a senior staff attorney at the Community Tax Law Project âThis is especially detrimental to taxpayers who may be eligible to claim the Earned Income Tax Credit,â she said. The EITC is a benefit available to low and moderate-income taxpayers who could be eligible for up to a $6,557 tax refund for 2019 with three or more qualifying children, according to the IRS. While people who make under $12,000 arenât required to file a tax return to pay taxes, they do need to file one if they want to claim the Earned Income Tax Credit. âTaxpayers who use the portal to claim their stimulus checks will need to file a paper return to claim the EITC which may take several weeks if not months to process as the IRS is still trying to catch up on its backlog of mail,â Rossner told MarketWatch.Â (The IRS did not respond to MarketWatchâs request for a comment.) She recommends that people who qualify for the EITC consult with a tax professional who can give quick advice on whether to use the portal to claim their stimulus check more quickly or file their 2019 tax return, which would trigger the stimulus check payment and the EITC refund.Â Also see: Should I have gotten my stimulus check by now? Why some people are still waiting â and what to do about it Prior to the coronavirus pandemic, low-income Americans had access to free in-person tax prep assistance from Volunteer Income Tax Assistance and Tax Counseling for the Elderly, both of which are federally funded programs. However, many of the offices for those programs have closed or are operating with limited capabilities due to the COVID-19 pandemic, Rossner said, â[I]t has created a perfect storm challenging low-income Americansâ ability to access their stimulus checks which they are rightfully entitled to.â Organizations like the Community Tax Law Project can help Americans figure out which option is best for them, Rossner said.Â Why are so many Americans are still waiting for stimulus checks?Â So far, the IRS has distributed checks to more than 160 million Americans as part of the $2 trillion CARES Act stimulus package. The payments amount to $1,200 for individuals who earn up to $75,000. Married couples earning under $150,000 received $2,400.Â âThe problem is that the program was structured as a tax refund, so the IRS needs people to file a tax return, but people who do not normally file returns donât realize that they need to,â said Lauren Saunders, associate director at the National Consumer Law Center, a nonprofit that advocates for consumersâ rights on issues. “ âThe problem is that the program was structured as a tax refund, so the IRS needs people to file a tax return, but people who do not normally file returns donât realize that they need to.â ” â Lauren Saunders, associate director at the National Consumer Law Center On top of this, âthe IRS does not readily have information available about people who donât file tax returns and donât receive federal benefits,â she added.Â âAnother factor is weâve seen a lot of taxpayers who have been claimed as dependents without their knowledge or their preparers made a mistake that is causing them not to get their payment or the full amount of it,â said Omeed Firouzi, a staff attorney at Philadelphia Legal Assistance, a free legal service providerâs low-income tax clinic. Some people also may not be able to access their payment âbecause it went to a joint bank account they no longer have full access to anymore,â he added. See also: Domestic abusers are taking survivorsâ stimulus checks â and lawmakers want the IRS to do something about it Â It can be difficult to navigate obstacles to overcome these situations, Firouzi said. Getting help often involves filing amended returns, wrangling with the IRS, getting in touch with the Taxpayer Advocate Service (an independent organization within the IRS) âand waiting a long time for matters to resolve,â he said. âIt is unfortunate that the people who need the money the most need to jump through hoops and might miss out, but we donât have a national tracking system to find people,â Saunders said.
